I.   INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Fiji recognizes that strong public financial management (PFM) is key 
to  macroeconomic  stability  and  poverty  reduction.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical 
assistance  (TA)  will  support  the  implementation  of  Fiji’s  Public  Financial  Management 
Improvement Programme (PFMIP) 2016–2019 by improving institutional capacity for reform and 
reform coordination.1 Implementing the PFMIP will help promote fiscal discipline, the strategic 
allocation of resources, and efficient service delivery. 
 
2.  The TA is included in the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country operations business 
plan for Fiji, 2017–2019,2 and is aligned to the National Development Plan 2017−2036,3 which 
focuses  on  improving  public  sector  efficiency  and  incentivizing  more  efficient  allocation  of 
resources  to  enhance  good  governance  and  support  sustainable  growth  in  key  economic 
sectors.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Development context. Fiji is one of the more developed Pacific island countries, but 
faces significant challenges related to the country’s small size and remote location. Fiji’s economy 
has outperformed those of most other Pacific islands countries in 2014–2016, with steady growth 
since FY2010, longer than any period since independence in 1970. However, this expansion is 
largely  driven  by  the  public  sector,  with  private  investment  discouraged  by  Fiji’s  high-cost 
business and investment environment.5 Moreover, Fiji’s vulnerability to natural disasters such as 
cyclones and floods has contributed to volatility in growth. Growth in FY2016 fell to .4% following 
extensive damage caused by Cyclone Winston, a reduction from 4.7% during FY2013–FY2015. 
In FY2017 post-cyclone reconstruction combined with large public infrastructure investments to 
drive growth resulted in government debt increasing to an estimated 45.5% of gross domestic 
product (GDP), with budget deficits rising to 7.4%. Fiji’s debt is expected to rise further to 47.3% 
of GDP in FY2018, which is close to the limit of the government’s public debt ceiling of 50% of 
GDP;6 this leaves limited fiscal space to further stimulate growth and respond to shocks such as 
natural disasters. In response the government has adopted a medium-term fiscal adjustment 
program based on maintaining the budget deficit at less than 3.0% of GDP and reducing the debt 
stock to 40% of GDP (footnote 6). 
 
4.  Reform agenda. The government recognizes that achieving a sound fiscal position 
requires sound policies, systems, and processes. A strong PFM system is regarded as vital to 
macroeconomic stability, and is a key ingredient for sustained growth and poverty reduction. A 
public expenditure and financial accountability (PEFA) assessment undertaken in 2013 (footnote 
1) provided the government an opportunity to evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of Fiji’s 
PFM system. The PEFA identified improvements that had taken place in 2010–2013, and also 
highlighted  several  weaknesses  and  challenges.  On  the  basis  of  the  PEFA  findings,  the 
government developed and adopted the PFMIP, which outlines a time-bound action plan to

implement critical and ambitious PFM reforms. It includes measures to strengthen institutions, 
improve service delivery, and enhance expenditure quality. 
 
5.  Implementing  the  Public  Financial  Management  Improvement  Programme. 
Implementation of the PFMIP is central to the government’s efforts to achieve a strong PFM 
system. Steady progress is being made and recent PFM improvements include (i) simplification 
of tax laws, systems, and processes through amendments to the Income Tax Act; (ii) introduction 
of  pay-as-you-earn  as  a  final  tax  and  value-added  tax  self-assessment;  (iii)  inclusion  of 
performance management in budget documents at the program and activity level, and tracking of 
the implications of new policy decisions; (iv) submission of annual procurement plans and their 
publication  on  the  Ministry  of  Economy  (MOE)  website;  (v)  amendment  of  procurement 
regulations to tighten the conditions for the waiver of competitive bids; and (vi) development of a 
debt management strategy and processes for evaluation of guarantees and onlending. However, 
the government recognizes that additional reforms are essential, and that the pace of reform must 
be accelerated to create the required fiscal space. 
 
6.  Major  reforms  prioritized for  implementation  during  2018–2020  include  (i)  improving 
overall budget reliability by strengthening the recording and monitoring of expenditure arrears; (ii) 
conducting public expenditure reviews of the education and health sectors; (iii) improving the link 
between  policy  priorities  and  resource  allocation  through  the  incorporation  of  multiyear 
perspectives  in  fiscal  planning,  expenditure  policy,  and  budgeting;  and  (iv)  improving  the 
completeness and timeliness of accounts reconciliation, including payroll and advance accounts. 
 
7.  The MOE has identified three major factors critical to accelerating the implementation of 
high-priority reforms: 
(i)  Improving the institutional capacity for reform. Fiji’s small population and 
continued high migration rate have contributed to a shortage of qualified staff, and 
subsequent weak institutional capacity for reform. A PFM capacity development 
program, prepared as part of the PFMIP,7 has identified and prioritized the need to 
address the following skills gaps: 
(a)  technical  skills,  through  training  in  basic  procurement,  public  policy 
analysis, budget analysis, revenue forecasting, debt analysis, and cash 
flow management; 
(b)  management  skills,  through  training  in  basic  management  functions, 
delegation and time management, handling of difficult conversations, and 
negotiations; and 
(c)  leadership  skills,  through  training  in  leadership,  motivating  staff,  and 
managing the political economy. 
(ii)  Improving reform coordination within and outside the government. There is 
no  government-led  PFM  reform  coordination  mechanism.  The  internal  PFM 
Reform Steering Committee (led by the MOE) is largely inactive because of high 
turnover of experienced staff within the MOE, poor transition arrangements and 
handover  practices,  and  overstretched  management  capacity.  In  addition, 
although PFM TA is being provided by the Government of Australia, ADB, the 
Pacific Financial Technical Assistance Center, and the World Bank, TA needs are 
discussed on a bilateral basis, with limited information sharing. 
(iii)  Restructuring  the  Ministry  of  Economy  to  improve  provision  of  core 
functions. Coordination and collaboration within and across MOE divisions and 
units  can  be  strengthened  to  improve  MOE  service  delivery  and  overall 
                                                
7  Government of Fiji. 2016. Fiji PFM Capacity Development Program. Suva.

3 
effectiveness. The MOE has 372 staff positions, but just under half (48.4%) were 
filled as of 31 December 2016. The professional cadre—comprising qualified 
accountants, auditors, and economists—makes up about 25% of the workforce, 
and most of the middle and senior management positions. Working closely with 
the government’s Civil Service Reform Unit,8 the MOE undertook internal reviews 
of its units and divisions to determine whether a new structure was needed to 
improve  service  delivery  efficiency  and  effectiveness.  A  new  structure  was 
subsequently approved (in August 2017) that improves the alignment between the 
policy and operating environments, and up to 70% of all positions have now been 
filled. 
 
8.  ADB support. The ADB TA will support recruitment of international and national experts 
in fiscal policy, budget management, financial management, public procurement, and knowledge 
management to help the MOE address the factors identified above, and thereby improve its 
institutional capacity to implement the PFMIP and strengthen reform coordination. In so doing, 
the TA will also support the implementation of potential elements of subprogram 2 of a planned 
$180 million programmatic policy-based loan operation. Likely areas of support to be reflected in 
the subprogram include public expenditure reviews, monitoring and recording of expenditure 
arrears, debt management, and budget strengthening. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  inclusive  socioeconomic  development 
(footnote 3). The TA will have the following outcome: PFM improved.9 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
10.  The outputs of the TA will be (i) institutional capacity to implement the PFMIP improved, 
and  (ii)  reform  coordination  between  government  agencies  and  development  partners 
strengthened. To achieve the outputs, the TA will establish and fund a PFM reform coordination 
unit (RCU) comprising four consultants (three international and one national) and three dedicated 
MOE counterpart staff as local reform champions. The RCU will report to the permanent secretary 
for economy (PSE), and be led by a credible and experienced international consultant (advisor to 
the PSE and team leader). The team leader will supervise the other international consultants 
(RCU advisors) and the national consultant, manage daily liaisons between the PSE and the RCU, 
advise on human resources development and process improvements, and provide regular reports 
to the PFM Reform Steering Committee on the status of reform implementation. 
 
11.  Output 1: Institutional capacity to implement the Public Financial Management 
Improvement Programme improved. Under the overall oversight of the PSE, the RCU will 
support  implementation  of  the  PFMIP  through  ongoing  mentoring,  capacity  building,  and 
interactive training of counterpart staff. The RCU will help formulate a clear operational work plan 
and change-management strategy, and monitor their implementation in support of the PFMIP 
strategic outcomes and priorities (e.g., public expenditure reviews for health and education, and 
the adoption of a medium-term expenditure framework). The RCU will provide at least eight

structured training sessions per year for government staff on relevant topics to be identified in 
consultation with the PSE. The RCU will also provide regular briefings for decision makers through 
seminars and interactive training support for policy formulation and data analysis; support the 
production of PFM updates; and produce regular, user-friendly, knowledge briefs and videos and 
analytical pieces. 
 
12.  The team leader will advise the PSE on all matters related to PFM reform. The RCU 
advisors will work with the departments responsible for budgeting and planning; fiscal policy, 
research and analysis; and financial policy and accounting services . The RCU will advise the 
heads of these departments on the implementation of high-priority reforms (paragraph 6), and 
support  the  implementation  of  subprogram  2  reform  actions  (paragraph  8).  The  national 
consultant will work closely with the team leader and RCU advisors and across all functional areas 
to produce user-friendly knowledge materials and short videos. 
 
13.  Output 2: Reform coordination between government agencies and development 
partners strengthened. The team leader will liaise with development partners and external 
agencies on PFMIP implementation to ensure reform efforts are coordinated, complementary and 
aligned with the PFMIP. The PFM Reform Steering Committee will be reactivated to strengthen 
internal coordination. The RCU will support the MOE’s efforts to improve line ministry awareness 
of the PFMIP and the government’s broader fiscal strategies and policies. 
 
14.  The TA will support the MOE in establishing a government-led PFM reform coordination 
mechanism to improve coordination with key partners that support PFM reforms (e.g., the 
Government of Australia, ADB, the Pacific Financial Technical Assistance Center, and the World 
Bank). With support from the RCU, the MOE will strengthen coordination to ensure that PFM 
reform efforts achieve timely results, while avoiding duplicative or contradictory advice from 
development partners. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $825,000, of which $750,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items 
are  listed  in  Appendix  2.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of 
counterpart  staff,  office  accommodation,  office  supplies,  secretarial  assistance,  domestic 
transportation, and other in-kind contributions. The TA will also act to improve development 
partner coordination through cofinancing and joint analytical work. In this respect, additional 
development partner financing is expected during TA implementation. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will administer the TA. The MOE will be the executing and implementing agency. 
Consultant recruitment will be managed by ADB but the consultants will report to the PSE. The 
consultants will operate as the RCU under the supervision of the team leader, who will be the 
liaison point with the PSE. Procurement of goods and services are envisaged for various activities 
such as training, seminars and conferences. Procurement will follow ADB’s Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and the Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, 
as amended from time to time).

17.  Consulting services. The TA is expected to require 36 person-months of individual 
consultant  services  (30  person-months  of  international  consultant  and  6  person-months  of 
national consultant services, all intermittent). The consultants will be selected by the first quarter 
of 2018. The consultants will have expertise in fiscal policy, budget management, financial 
management  (international  consultants),  and  publications  and  video  production  (national 
consultant).  Consultants  will  require  a  track record  in  training  and  capacity  building.  Each 
consultant will be recruited on an individual consultant selection basis and on output-based 
contracts. They will be required to submit quarterly progress reports to the MOE for review of their 
performance;  their  performance  will  be  evaluated  more  frequently  through  assessments 
conducted  as  part  of  annual  country  programming,  International  Monetary  Fund  Article  IV 
consultations  and/or  staff  missions;  the  Government  of  Australia’s  Assessment  of  national 
systems; and the next PEFA assessment (scheduled for mid-2018). All consultants will be 
recruited in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Policy and the associated project administration 
instructions and TA staff instructions).10 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Fiji for Supporting Public Financial Management Reform, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.
